weekByWeekBreakdown.focus: Establish study routine: 60min focused study (choose ONE skill/subject), 15 pages reading (related books), 10min journaling (consolidate learnings), 5min meditation (pre-study focus), social media <90min, wake 7am. Build foundation.
Increase study to 90min. Implement active recall (no passive reading—test yourself constantly). Meditation before study sharpens focus. Notice learning velocity increasing.
Study 2 hours daily. Add spaced repetition (review Day 1 notes today, Day 7 notes tomorrow). Reading 20 pages. Journal connects concepts across sources. Mental models forming.
Thanksgiving week: study through chaos. Others coast, you compound. 2+ hours daily (non-negotiable). This discipline separates learners from dabblers.
December begins: darkest month = deepest focus. Study 2.5 hours (peak cognitive hours: 6-9am post-wake). Reading 25 pages. You're retaining everything now.
Mid-winter mastery emerging. Notice expertise developing in chosen subject. Meditation 10min improves information processing. Social media <60min (time reallocated to learning).
Holiday chaos (Christmas/New Year): everyone parties, you study. 2+ hours daily through Dec 25-Jan 1. This commitment defines transformation. Knowledge compounds during others' breaks.
January: they're starting resolutions. You have 130+ hours focused study completed, 1,200+ pages read. Expertise visible. People asking YOU questions now.
Final intensity: 3 hours study daily, 30 pages reading, 15min journaling (synthesis of all learnings), 15min meditation, social media <30min, wake 6am. Maximum learning velocity.
Day 66: 150+ hours focused study, 15+ books read, 66 journal entries documenting journey from novice to near-expert. Compare knowledge Dec 1 vs now: unrecognizable. Spring launches your expertise.

commonPitfalls: Studying too many subjects (choose ONE for 66 days—depth beats breadth)
Passive consumption (reading without active recall = entertainment, not learning)
Not scheduling study time (2+ hours daily requires morning commitment)
Skipping journaling (reflection consolidates knowledge—don't skip this)
Linear reading (spaced repetition + active recall required for retention)
Social media 'research' rabbit holes (focus time is sacred—no distractions)
Quitting during holiday weeks (Dec 24-Jan 1 study time separates amateurs from experts)
